content.description: Climb the right side of the Y crack. There are two bolts up high. This is an excellent route!

Amos had great vision with this power packed, mixed route on the far left side of the Difficult West Crag! It was named after Amos’ 6 year old son Caspian spitting out his PB&J sandwich made with spicy jalapeño jelly by his climbing fanatic dad in a rush.

Start 7 feet left of  “

Mosquito Banquet

” on the arete. Power up steep, arete flake feature with hand-sized pro. Clip a bolt above crack/flare. Transition into a very powerful bear hug boulder problem. Above second bolt, head right, and finish on “

Mosquito Banquet

“.

Where the trail meets first meets Difficult Cliff are a selection of trad routes. The first route on the left is "

Mosquito Banquet

", a nice route with a bit of offwidth that goes at 10a.

The next line to the right is a Y-shaped crack, both variations being 5.12.

The next line right is "The Product", Old school 10d.

climbs.name: Pipeline (formerly listed as Sex Wax)
climbs.fa: Steve Shea and Bob Wade, bolted by Tom Perkins & Neal Beidleman?

content.description: At the left end of Difficult Wall is a long, flaring corner.  Climb up this corner using a variety of techniques.  The original route, called Pipeline, exited left at the top of the flare.  Keep the amplitude high by stepping right into an overhanging corner.

climbs.name: No Tengo Miedo
climbs.fa: T. Perkins, M.J. Golau, N. Beidleman

content.description: This is a fantastic route that goes through two roofs with a slab in between. It is spicy and thoughtful for the onsight.
content.protection: 8 bolts and 1 pin (extend at the pin or unclip it once the bolt above is clipped).
content.location: To the left of the main "Difficult Wall West", this bolt line goes through the roofs left of the large, left-facing corner.

content.description:
This was rated .10 a in the guidebook back in 1972. Haha.

You get great jamming with some body English.
content.location: This is on the left side of "Difficult Wall West's" main wall.

content.description:
Climb the beautiful and steep (sometimes powerful), right-trending weakness to mid point on the wall. Use caution when passing some stacked blocks at around bolt(s) 3 or 4. A great rest follows the steeper stuff. Tricky moves back left (the entire route climbs near the arete that defines the outer edge of the

Daredevil

dihedral) to the arete are followed by some steep slabbing for 30+ feet to the chains. Continuous and really, really fun. Very well protected. One of the best routes of its grade on The Pass!
content.location:
This is the rightmost route on the upper section of Difficult Campground Wall. Identify it as being one route right of the obvious and also beautiful

Daredevil

(5.9) hand crack / dihedral.

content.description: Scramble up broken terrain towards the slot/chimney. Going over the chockstone will keep the rope free. This is PG-13 as the chimney is difficult to protect.
content.protection: A single rack to #3 and a large double length sling for the chockstone.
content.location:
To the left of the main "Difficult West" Wall, between a large, left-facing corner and some roofs. It shares anchor with "

No Tenga Miedo

."

content.description:
Climb the crack system 10 feet left of the “

The Product

” start. Climb hands to fingers through a small bulge. Then move into an amazing boulder problem with pinches and crux slopers. Bust right at second horizontal. Follow a finger crack for 5 feet, then finish with the upper crux of the “

The Product

”. This definitely took some elbow grease/cleaning to make it a fun route! This was Northwest style cleaning of dirt, moss, and choss!
content.protection: A standard rack, tips to 2.5”, and 00 x 2.

content.description: This has great climbing from bottom to top! While maybe not a distinct crux, stepping left under/around the big roof will often get your heartrate up a beat or two. The upper section is as fun as it looks!
content.protection:
Big cams / hexes. A couple great wires can be slotted in on the lower section if you don't want to drag too much big stuff. A gray (#3.5) Camalot under the roof protects the step out really well. There were a couple (old...) fixed pins in the upper dihedral.

There are chain anchors.
content.location: This ascends an obvious dihedral, marked by a big roof at mid-height, on the lower section of the upper wall.

content.description:
Bird's Nest is a great route with jamming and stemming along with a thin traverse.

Go up the dihedral, and exit left at the roof to the anchors.
content.protection: A rack to 3", doubles in mid-range.
content.location: It is on Difficult Wall East (uphill). See the picture.
